unnormalised: **Energy & Utilities: Load Shedding Persists in Northern States**
normalised: **Energy and Utilities: Load Shedding Persists in Northern States**

unnormalised: New Delhi, Oct 26, 2023 - Unscheduled load shedding continues to plague several northern states, impacting both domestic and industrial consumers. Power discoms in Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan are struggling to meet peak demand, resulting in outages lasting up to 4 hours in some areas.
normalised: New Delhi, october twenty sixth, two thousand and twenty three - Unscheduled load shedding continues to plague several northern states, impacting both domestic and industrial consumers. Power discoms in Uttar Pradesh and Rajasthan are struggling to meet peak demand, resulting in outages lasting up to four hours in some areas.

unnormalised: Dr. Sharma, Director of the Central Electricity Authority, attributed the situation to a combination of factors, including delayed coal deliveries to thermal power plants and ongoing maintenance work on transmission lines. The Northern Regional Load Despatch Centre (NRLDC) is working with state utilities to optimize power allocation.
normalised: Doctor Sharma, Director of the Central Electricity Authority, attributed the situation to a combination of factors, including delayed coal deliveries to thermal power plants and ongoing maintenance work on transmission lines. The N R L D C is working with state utilities to optimize power allocation.

unnormalised: Small businesses, particularly those in the textile hub of Surat, Gujarat, are reportedly incurring losses due to disrupted production. Mr. Patel, a local businessman, estimated losses at Rs. 50,000 per day for businesses operating in units of 5,000 sq ft. Officials have assured that efforts are underway to alleviate the situation by importing additional power and expediting repairs. Consumers are urged to conserve electricity during peak hours. The next review meeting is scheduled for Nov 2nd.
normalised: Small businesses, particularly those in the textile hub of Surat, Gujarat, are reportedly incurring losses due to disrupted production. Mister Patel, a local businessman, estimated losses at rupee fifty thousand per day for businesses operating in units of five thousand square feet. Officials have assured that efforts are underway to alleviate the situation by importing additional power and expediting repairs. Consumers are urged to conserve electricity during peak hours. The next review meeting is scheduled for november second.
